title: NY Attorney General sues loan servicer, says it ‘failed miserably’ to process student-debt forgiveness applications
text:
The loan servicer handling student-debt forgiveness requests is badly bungling the job and misleading borrowers who deserve a clean slate, New York’s attorney general charged in a lawsuit filed Thursday.

Approximately 99% of all Public Service Loan Forgiveness applicants have been rejected and FedLoan’s alleged failures are “a significant contributor to the shockingly high rate of rejection,” the New York attorney general’s office contended. FedLoan has “failed miserably,” the office added.

Among other accusations, the agency’s Thursday lawsuit accused the Pennsylvania-based servicer of miscounting eligible payments and giving borrowers bad information about how to achieve loan forgiveness. The eligible-payments count is important because borrowers only get the loan forgiveness after they’ve made 10 years of payments.

FedLoan and its parent entity, the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency (PHEAA), are already fighting a similar case filed by the Massachusetts Attorney General’s office, among other consumer lawsuits that have been filed against them.

FedLoan is the sole company in charge of servicing loans under the controversy-plagued Public Service Loan Forgiveness program.

The PSLF program is designed to wipe away the student-loan debt of people who work in public service jobs such as teaching and nursing. The program went into effect in 2007. Borrowers must make 10 years of qualifying payments before they are eligible for forgiveness. So far only about 1% (1,526) of the more than 100,000 people who have applied for the financial relief have received it, according to the Education Department.

That’s partly because eligibility details are very complicated, including what sort of loan can be forgiven, which employers are considered a “qualifying employer” and which repayment plans are eligible.

At a recent Congressional hearing, an Education Department official acknowledged the program has “numerous obstacles.”

But borrowers are also getting misleading information from FedLoan about the program’s terms, the New York attorney general’s lawsuit contended.

On Thursday, New York Attorney General Letitia James said hard-working public servants have been getting “nothing but the runaround and broken promises.” PHEAA’s alleged “abuses have not only denied these dedicated public servants the benefits they have earned, but have undermined the goals of the loan-forgiveness program,” she added.

The servicer is ready to fight the case, a PHEAA spokesman said.

“Over the years, PHEAA has cooperatively worked with the New York AG’s Office, along with many other regulators throughout the nation, to review specific borrower concerns and to identify and implement appropriate resolutions as they arise,” he said.

PHEAA learned last month that James’ office planned to sue and “repeatedly requested to meet with the NY AG’s Office but the NY AG’s Office declined our efforts.”

Lawmakers invited PHEAA to the Congressional hearing last month, but the organization declined the invite. Democratic lawmakers fumed over the perceived snub, pointing out the federal government paid PHEAA $1.3 billion for the contract to handle forgiveness applications.

Complexity isn’t the only reason approval rates are low, according to some critics. They contend borrowers have been misled and mistreated. The American Federation of Teachers is suing the Education Department for allegedly mismanaging the plan.

The Education Department previously said it’s been “faithfully administering the complex program Congress passed.”
description: The new lawsuit adds to pressure against FedLoan’s 99% rejection rate of loan-forgiveness applications.
